metadata.title: Breast Cancer  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: carcinoma of the breast: occupational therapy
anatomical location body part affected: The breast, including the nipple and areola, the large ducts and terminal duct-lobular  unit, surrounding adipose and fibrous tissue, lymphatics, nerves, and blood vessels. The axillary tail of the breast comprises mammary tissue and extends laterally from the chest wall into the axilla.(1) From a rehabilitation perspective, the entire limb may be affected (e.g., shoulder, lymphedema, axillary web) and the patient may also have generalized fatigue and cognitive issues(20)
description: Breast cancer is carcinoma of the female or male breast; however, 99% of breast cancers occur in females.(2) Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women in the United States and is second to lung cancer as the most common cause of death related to cancer(19)
In the United States there are approximately 271,270 new breast cancer patients annually and there is an annual mortality rate of around 42,260(2)

Breast cancer is an invasive carcinoma of the breast which may be ductal or lobular.(2) It is staged using a TNM (tumor, regional lymph nodes, distant metastases) system, in which each component is assessed and classified(13)

Histologically there are a number of types of breast cancers, including infiltrating ductal (e.g., medullary, tubular, papillary), invasive lobular, noninvasive (e.g., intraductal, lobular in situ), juvenile, adenoid cystic, and epidermoid(13)

Early-stage  cancer (in situ or absence of invasion of the tumor cells into surrounding tissues) includes DCIS, which can progress to Paget’s disease of the nipple, which is a direct extension of DCIS into the lactiferous ducts and adjacent skin(1)

Invasive carcinoma of the breast includes invasive ductal carcinoma (e.g., mucinous, tubular, medullary, micropapillary, papillary, or inflammatory carcinoma) and invasive lobular carcinoma (e.g., tubulolobular carcinoma)(1)
Pregnancy-associated  breast cancercan be diagnosed during pregnancy or up to 12 months postpartum(1)

A breast cancer survivor can have a variety of rehabilitation needs.(20) Many factors will influence the presentation of the individual patient (e.g., age; type of cancer; surgical, radiation, and medical treatment regimen; premorbid health; comorbidities) –Shoulder dysfunction (pain, limited ROM) –Lymphedema –Axillary web syndrome –Pain –Fatigue –Decreased upper extremity (UE) strength and endurance –Impaired sensation
Non-physical  rehabilitation needs may also be present(23)  –Cognitive dysfunction –Occupational issues/return to work –Psychosocial and QOL –Social function, mood, coping

C50.ICD-10-CA: ICD-10-CA  modification in Canada: code range C50.0-C50.9  subdivided and fourth digit added to identify

D05.D05.7: other carcinoma in situ of breast
D05.D05.9: carcinoma in situ of breast, unspecified

ICD-10 codes.R92: abnormal findings on diagnostic imaging of breast
ICD-10 codes.Z80.3: family history of malignant neoplasm of breast
ICD-10 codes.Z85.3: personal history of malignant neoplasm of breast (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The patient may be free of any physical findings,(2) or may have any of the following signs and symptoms –Breast pain(1,3) –Breast tenderness(1) –Change in the size or shape of the breast(1) –Clear, serous, or bloody nipple discharge(1,2) –Nodule enlargement in axilla and supraclavicular areas(2) –Palpable lump or mass in the breast(1,2) –Redness/rash on the breast(1) –Skin or nipple retraction(3) –Skin edema, ulcer, or satellite nodule(2) –Generalized symptoms in metastatic cases include:(2) -fatigue -weight loss -jaundice -anorexia
In patients who have no symptoms at the time of diagnosis, tumors may have been detected on a routine mammogram(1)

A breast cancer survivor may have deficits in a number of areas, both physical and non-physical,  that interfere with function and that can be addressed by occupational therapy (OT) intervention. Presentation will depend upon the nature of the deficits. More common presentations include the following: –Shoulder dysfunction(20) -The incidence of shoulder dysfunction following surgery is reported to be between 17% and 70% –Axillary web syndrome(21) -Formation of taut cords and axillary adhesions that may be painful and limit UE ROM. They typically form between 1 to 5 weeks after lymph node dissection, but can form years after surgery -For additional information on axillary web syndrome, see Clinical Review…Axillary Web Syndrome; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709210 –Chemotherapy-induced  polyneuropathy (CIPN)(24) -Most commonly seen in patients receiving taxanes, vinca alkaloids, or platinum-based  chemotherapy agents -May cause gait issues and instability as well as fine motor coordination issues –Cognitive issues including impairments in memory, attention, executive functioning, and processing speed(22) –Lymphedema(20) -For additional information about lymphedema in breast cancer, see  Clinical Review…Lymphedema Following Surgical Treatment for Breast Cancer ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709193 –Fatigue, defined as a persistent sense of tiredness that interferes with normal function. This may be a barrier to rehabilitation(20) –Pain(20) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes:: The exact cause of breast cancer is unknown(2)
The underlying etiology of breast cancer in women is likely related to an interaction of ovarian estrogen, nonovarianestrogen, and estrogens of exogenous origin with breast tissue(2)
For about 10% of all women with breast cancer, there is an associated mutation of the BRCA1  gene and/or BRCA2  genethat appears to cause the development of cancer(1,2,3)

Molecular classification based on gene expression profiling:(2)–Luminal A type: endocrine responsive with favorable prognosis–Luminal B type: endocrine responsive with less favorable prognosis–Tumors resemble normal epithelium–HER-2  (Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) amplified type: HER-2  gene amplification–Basal type: hormone receptor and HER-2  negative cancers with poor prognosis

Triple negative tumors: subset of breast carcinomas that are negative for the three usual markers (HER-2,  estrogenreceptors[ER], and progesterone receptors[PR]); typically occur in younger women and have a poor prognosis(1)

The functional deficits seen in breast cancer survivors are often related to the side effects of the treatments, includingsurgery, radiation, or chemotherapy,(20) but may also be related to the cancer itself (e.g., pathologic fracture secondary tobone metastases)
pathogenesis: Breast cancer is more likely to be diagnosed in the central or outer quadrants of the breast than the inner regions; alsoslightly more common in the left breast(1)

Within the breast, the tumor can travel along the ducts and can erode the basement membrane of the breast(1)–Continued growth can result in spread of the tumor to adjacent lobules, breast lymphatics, nerves, and vascular spaces;additional growth can then involve the pectoralis and intercostal muscles, ribs, and clavicle(1)

Metastasis of breast cancer to other parts of the body can occur through direct extension, lymphatic, or intravascularmeans(1)–Although breast cancer can metastasize to any organ, the most commonly involved sites are the lungs, bones, lymphnodes, and liver; the next most common sites are the pleural space, adrenal glands, and brain(1)

overall contraindications precautions: After breast surgery, the patient should be encouraged to(5) take breaks when traveling for extended distances (getting out of the vehicle and ambulating a bit is helpful in promoting circulation) support the impaired extremity during travel as able keep sodium ingestion to a minimum and strive to sustain ideal body weight  don compression garments prior to exercise have blood pressure taken on the uninvolved side monitor skin closely and attend to blisters, burns, insect bites, cuts, or abrasions keep skin clean and avoid lotion with perfume safeguard hands and feet with socks or hose, gloves, oven mitts, and properly fitting shoes be careful when trimming nails and when shaving use an electric razor wear sun-protective  clothing outdoors avoid waxing and electrolysis

After breast surgery, the patient should not(5) wear restrictive clothing or tight jewelry use local heat or spend time in hot environments allow injections, blood draws, or blood pressure to be taken in the involved extremity, as able allow skin contact with harsh chemicals/detergents raise the body’s core temperature (in whirlpools, saunas, or hot baths) maintain fixed and dependent positions of the legs or involved UE cross lower extremities while sitting
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: A client-centered  approach includes the following principles: –The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about his or her occupational functioning(6) –The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(6) –The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent(6) –Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc.(6) –When the patient is able to define the problems that he or she would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver(6) –The patient should evaluate his or her own performance and set personal goals(6)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was breast cancer diagnosed in the patient? -Review medical history, including date of any surgeries (lumpectomy or mastectomy); biopsy results; the patient’s prior and current chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and/or drug regimen; and other medical management of the breast cancer to date(1) -When did the survivor begin experiencing deficits during the course of treatment?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of patients with breast cancer will vary depending on the stage and type of breast cancer. Therapeutic options for patients with noninvasive or invasive breast cancer are complex and varied(19) Early-stage  breast cancers are primarily treated with surgery (typically modified mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment, which consists of lumpectomy, axillary staging with sentinel node biopsy, or axillary dissection) alone or surgery in combination with radiation therapy(2) Patients sometimes require chemotherapy and/or endocrine therapy in addition to surgery and radiation therapy(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the patient has been prescribed; are they being taken? What are the common side effects of the medications (e.g., peripheral neuropathy, hair loss)? Standard chemotherapy for breast cancer typically consists of cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and fluorouracil; cyclophosphamide plus doxorubicin; or doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide plus taxane(2) Endocrine therapy is indicated after chemotherapy for patients with hormone-receptor-positive  tumors(2)
diagnostic tests completed: Because of inconsistencies in clinical examination, a thorough imaging workup of a palpable mass should be completed prior to biopsy(18)
Review any available diagnostic test results; diagnostic tests for breast cancer include the following:
Recommended for women with breast implants and when there is a strong family history of breast cancer(2)
Able to identify the primary tumor in patients who present with axillary adenopathy(2)
PET scan and/or CT scan of the brain, liver, and/or abdomen to rule out metastasis(1,3)
Genetic testing for BRCA1 gene and BRCA2  gene mutations(3)
Used in patients with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer(3)
Laboratory tests include complete blood cell count (CBC), chemistry panel, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture),what they are used for, and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had psychotherapy, occupational therapy, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any factors that appear to improve or aggravate the patient’s current symptoms; also note the length of time before symptoms come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Complaints of back or other bone pain can indicate possible osseous metastases; report these complaints to the patient’s physician for additional diagnostic workup(3) -Chemotherapy-induced  peripheral neuropathy may impact the UE and lower extremity (LE)(24)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Characterized by continuous pain in the axilla, medial upper arm, and lateral chest wall beginning immediately post-surgery -Often treated with pain medications; however, skin desensitization and exercises can also serve to alleviate this chronic pain syndrome -Patients undergoing chemotherapy may have chemotherapy-induced  polyneuropathy(24) -Cancer-related  fatigue -A 010  Likert-type  scale can be used to screen for fatigue, in which a rating of 13 is considered mild, 46 moderate, and 710 severe(28)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Chemotherapy can result in menopausal symptoms such as hot flashes, bone loss, and amenorrhea(1) -Axillary web syndrome can cause significant morbidity in a patient who has undergone axillary surgery; characterized by axillary pain that radiates down the patient’s arm, medial aspect, and sometimes the wrist; it can restrict motion of the shoulder and arm; usually resolves spontaneously within 3 months; however, patients often benefit from education and shoulder exercises as well(45) -Increase in falls may result from CIPN. Referral to the oncologist; medication or dosage changes may be appropriate to decrease symptoms -Unintentional weight loss can occur in patients with breast cancer and can indicate possible metastasis; discuss with the patient’s physician if the patient reports recent unintentional weight loss or an inability to maintain weight(3) -Patients recovering from treatment for breast cancer should be screened for psychosocial impairment, including depression and anxiety, as these issues frequently are associated with diagnosis of and recovery from breast cancer(1) -Cognitive complaints (e.g., decreased memory, attention, processing speed) may occur in breast cancer survivors(22) -Breast cancer survivors may experience cancer-related fatigue -For additional information regarding cancer and fatigue see Clinical Reviews…Cancer-Related  Fatigue and Exercise ,T709184; and Cancer-Related Fatigue , CINAHL Topic ID Number
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status -Patients with breast cancer who have been treated with radiation can develop symptomatic radiation pneumonitis; symptoms include dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever(1) -Concurrent chemotherapy increases the risk of developing pneumonitis(1) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a prior history of breast cancer? Has another type of cancer ever been diagnosed in the patient? When? How was it treated?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and osteoporosis Exposure of the heart to ionizing radiation during breast cancer radiotherapy increases the risk of ischemic heart disease. The increased rate of ischemic heart disease begins within a few years of exposure and continues for at least 20 years. This increase is proportional to the mean radiation dose to the heart(2) Coronary artery disease can be seen as a complication of breast cancer treatment(29)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What are the patient’s occupations and role(s) within his or her family, workplace, peer group, etc.? -What activities, hobbies, etc., does the patient enjoy? -A patient/caregiver interview may be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, current or prior work status, and home responsibilities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it be utilized based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?  -Does the patient have supportive family members? Do those family members live near and/or have the ability to provide assistance? -Does the patient have access to community resources?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Measure arm circumference using tape measure or volumetric measurements. Measure both affected and unaffected extremities -Prospective screening for lymphedema in breast cancer survivors that includes monitoring for arm volume changes using a perometer may help to identify and begin to treat lymphedema earlier(25) –Note BMI -BMI of 31.1 or higher is associated with a 2.5-fold greater risk of developing breast cancer as well as increased risk of breast cancer mortality(4)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or current use of assistive and adaptive devices –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthosis (AFOs) –Toileting and showering equipment -Grab bars -Bedside commode -A urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Shower chair/tub bench -Elevated foot rest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers -Smartphone -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software -Adaptive cooking equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADLs –Tinetti Balance Scale(8) –Berg Balance Scale –Functional Reach Test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale if indicated -Some chemotherapy drugs can cause cardiac and pulmonary toxicity; patients can also experience congestive heart failure (CHF); refer to a cardiologist if abnormalities of heart rate, shortness of breath, or chest pain present during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess cognitive status –Patients with breast cancer who have received chemotherapy sometimes report deficits in short-term  memory(1,22) –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is appropriate for patients with breast cancer(7,22)

contraindications precautions: Precautions for PROM should be followed for survivors with bone metastases

Lymphedema-related  contraindications/precautions -An OT providing lymphedema therapy should be specially trained in lymphatic massage and treatment of lymphedema(12) -Arterial blood flow should be confirmed prior to application of compression bandages/garments. Consult with patient’s physician prior to applying compression bandages/garments(5) -Absolute contraindications for manual lymphatic drainage include(5) -cellulitis -uncontrolled heart failure -acute renal failure -Relative contraindications for manual lymphatic drainage include(5) -skin adherence following radiation therapy -active cancer -unexplained pain -history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke -less than 3 months since surgery or radiation therapy -oral mucosal inflammation in patients with coexisting head and neck cancer
Cryotherapy contraindications(15) -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
Cryotherapy precautions(15) -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Electrotherapy contraindications/precautions(15) -Do not place electrodes near -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease -Malignancy  -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women

Low-level  laser therapy (LLLT) contraindications(15) -Do not use laser with pregnant women, patients with epilepsy, or patients with infections -Do not use over the unclosed fontanelles of children -Do not use over cancerous lesions, the mediastinum, areas of impaired sensation, sympathetic ganglia, the vagus nerve, the gonads, the cornea, endocrine glands, or hemorrhaging lesions
LLLT precautions(15) -Goggles with an appropriate optical density rating should be worn by the patient
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The OT will determine the need for intervention after a comprehensive evaluation; the OT must consider each patient’s risk factors (e.g., are there still cancerous lesions present and where) and functional deficits (e.g., impairments of ADL performance, fatigue, pain, ROM limitations) to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy
assessment plan of care.rule out: Prior to diagnosing breast cancer, the medical team will rule out fast Fourier transform (FFT) necrosis(3) fibrocystic changes of the breast(2,3) fibroadenoma(2,3) intraductal papilloma(3) hamartoma(2)
prognosis: Prognosis with curative therapy depends on the size of the tumor at the time of diagnosis, the presence and extent of nodal metastasis, and the pathological grade of the tumor(2) –Axillary node involvement is a strong predictor of relapse and mortality risk; risk increases as the number of nodes that are involved increases(1,2) –Tumor size is also a strong prognostic factor; increased risk of node involvement and recurrence as tumor size increases(1) -Clinical staging of breast cancer is based on the TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) system of the Union for International Cancer Control; the size of the tumor, node involvement, and presence or absence of metastasis is described in this method of staging(3) -Patients with small tumors that are estrogen and progesterone receptor-positive  have a more favorable prognosis(3) -Presence of lymphovascular invasion and high grade of tumor associated with worse prognosis(1)

The use of systematic adjuvant therapy improves prognosis significantly(2) –Women who take tamoxifen for 10 years lower their risk of recurrence by 25% and their risk of dying by 27% compared with those who take it for 5 years only(2) –In postmenopausal women with hormone-receptor-positive  breast cancer, adjuvant therapy with an aromatase inhibitor instead of tamoxifen improves survival outcomes(2) –Addition of zoledronic acid to adjuvant endocrine therapy increases disease-free  survival in premenopausal patients with estrogen-responsive  early-stage  breast cancer(2)

Isolated tumor cells or micrometastases in the regional lymph nodes are associated with a reduced rate of 5-year disease-free  survival for patients with favorable early-stage  breast cancer if adjuvant therapy is not received(2)
Prognosis for breast cancer in male patients is worse than for female patients(13)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to a psychologist, psychiatrist, and/or counselor for patients reporting symptoms of depression, anxiety, stress, fear of disease progression, or other psychosocial issues  –Patients with breast cancer have reported six core aspects of counseling that assist in recovery: focusing on self, exploring and expressing feelings, experiencing a helpful relationship, problem solving, experiencing relief and reassurance, and understanding others(33) Referral to palliative care for patients with advanced breast cancer and/or pain management needs(13) Referral to physical therapy for balance/mobility issues related to CIPN(27) Referral to a lymphedema-certified  physical or occupational therapist for lymphatic drainage For patients with significant cognitive impairment, referral to neuropsychology is appropriate for extensive assessment and input regarding cognitive intervention
treatment summary: Therapeutic exercise program –Authors of a meta-analysis  conducted in the South Korea found that getting at least 300 minutes a week of physical activity at a moderate intensity level lessens the risk of breast cancer death(39) -Based on 24 studies (N = 144,224) with a follow-up period of 1.9–12.7  years –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  conducted in Australia found that performing a combination of exercises that include aerobic and resistance training exercises at moderate to high intensity levels 3 to 5 times a week is safe and feasible for women with stage II+ cancer(40) –Researchers from Brazil found that patients receiving chemotherapy treatment for breast cancer can improve cardiorespiratory function with continuous or interval aerobic exercise training at a vigorous intensity level (64–90%  of VO2Max) (41) –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  recommend that patients with breast cancer participate in moderate to vigorous intensity exercise for at least 150 minutes 3 times a week during adjuvant therapy(42) –Researchers recommend moderate to vigorous intensity exercise for ≥ 50 minutes a week in order to improve fatigue, depression scores, and QOL in patients with breast cancer during active treatment(43) –Authors of a 2019 meta-analysis  found that the length of time a patient with breast cancer participates in an exercise session has an effect on the rate of improvement inQOL, social function, and physical function(44) -Participating in an exercise session between 45-90 minutes improved QOL of patients with breast cancer. Exercise sessions ≤ 45 minutes did not have any significant changes to QOL, social functioning, or physical functioning –Researchers in Germany who investigated the sustainable impact of an individualized exercise program on physical activity level and fatigue in breast cancer patients found that after 2 years, individuals in the intervention group showed a sustainable and significant increase in physical activity, significantly lower fatigue scores, and significantly improved health-related  QoL(36) -Quasi-randomized  controlled intervention trial that included 111 individuals in the intervention group and 83 in the control group -The intervention group received an individual 3-week exercise program with 2 additional 1-week  inpatient stays after 4 and 8 months as well as a home-based exercise program at the end. The control group received a 3-week  rehabilitation program only and no follow-up  care –Researchers in Australia who conducted an RCT found that an 8-month  exercise intervention for women beginning 6 weeks after surgery for breast cancer was effective for improving QoL over usual care (women received nothing except routine health care). They also found that it may be cost effective as well(37) -Intervention group received Exercise for Health delivered one-on-one,  either in person at home or over the phone –Researchers in Canada who conducted a pilot RCT of young adults with breast cancer (ages 18–45)  found that a targeted exercise program was no more effective than standard care in improving upper limb function and ability to return to work(38) -Outcome measures used were the DASH, the Metabolic Equivalent of Task-hours  per week (MET-hours/week) and a post hoc questionnaire on return to work

Fatigue –An observational study in Belgium tested the effect of a pedometer-based  physical activity device on women with breast cancer and healthy controls. All women in the study reported increased daily steps when using the pedometer. Researchers concluded that wearing the device might indicate that providing external feedback increases activity level(34) –In a systematic review designed to determine the pooled effects of supervised exercise on cancer-related  fatigue, investigators indicated that supervised exercise decreases fatigue and improves overall QOL in female breast cancer survivors(30) –In a randomized controlled study conducted in the Netherlands authors indicated that a supervised 18-week exercise program started within 6 weeks of diagnosis of breast cancer had positive effects on fatigue, submaximal cardiorespiratory fitness, and strength(26) -The exercise program consisted of two supervised 60-minute  aerobic and strength training sessions per week. The sessions were individualized based on the survivor’s preferences and fitness level -The survivors were also encouraged to engage in physical activity for at least 30 minutes on at least 3 additional days per week –Energy conservation and work simplification are strategies that can be used to improve function in survivors with fatigue(27) -Task prioritization -Recognition of need for assistance to allow for completion of meaningful activities

Lymphedema therapy(12) –Includes elevation of the arm, arm compression sleeves, strength training, arm care/hygiene education, use of a compression pump, and lymphatic massage(12) –Complex decongestive therapy (CDT)(32) -CDT is a treatment method for lymphedema that combines manual lymphatic drainage, compression bandages, therapeutic exercise, and skin and nail care –Laser therapy -Low-energy  laser focused on lymphatics in the axilla can be used to improve lymphatic flow(32) -Research on this treatment for lymphedema is in the initial stages; a review of the literature cited RCTs assessing LLLT. In one study of 55 patients comparing a placebo laser treatment with both one cycle of actual laser therapy and two cycles of actual laser therapy, researchers found that, compared to a placebo laser therapy, a one-cycle laser treatment was more effective than placebo but less effective than a two-cycle  laser treatment. These studies show moderate to strong evidence that LLLT is effective for management of lymphedema(32) –In obese patients, weight loss/changes in diet has also been found to be a useful treatment for lymphedema(32) –An OT providing lymphedema therapy should be specially trained in lymphatic massage and treatment of lymphedema(12) –For additional information on treatment of lymphedema, see  Clinical Review…Lymphedema  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708532 and Clinical Review…Lymphedema Following Surgical Treatment for Breast Cancer , referenced above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Fatigue; reduced strength and mobility of the upper extremityIncrease strength and functioning of the shoulder and upper extremity; increased energyTherapeutic modalities _ Resistance training program with or without aerobic exercise component _ _ _ Functional training _ Energy-conservation and work simplification strategies(27) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveGradual progression of intensity of exercises; increase the resistance, frequency, and/or duration of each exercise as the patient’s strength increasesProvide the patient and caregiver with simple ROM, strengthening exercises _ Prioritization of activities and asking for assistance for tasks to preserve energy for valued activities Pain, tenderness, swelling of the upper extremity and/or surgery siteResolve pain, tenderness, swelling of the upper extremity and/or surgery sitePhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Rest, ice, and elevation as indicated _ _ Therapeutic modalities _ ROM and strengthening exercises of the affected upper extremity _ _ Posture training to promote normal mechanics of the shoulderThe intensity and duration of exercises should be progressed as tolerated given the patient’s level of pain and functioningProvide the patient and caregiver with simple ROM, strengthening exercises as well as home protocol for pain management  Impairment of ADLs/ IADLsIncrease independence with ADLs/IADLs; increased safety and efficiency when performing ADLs/ IADLsFunctional training _ Upper extremity exercise program _ _ ADL/IADL training _ _ Adaptive equipment _ _ Teach use of adaptive equipment and techniques to increase independence in survivors with CIPN _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveGradual progression of intensity of exercises; increase the resistance, frequency, and/or duration of each exercise as the patient’s strength increases _ _ Initially, break ADL/ IADL tasks down into separate parts; with increased patient tolerance, have the patient perform progressively longer segments of each ADL/ IADL task at a timeCaregiver education is important for carryover of ADL/ IADL training into the home environment Lymphedema Reduce or eliminate lymphedemaPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Elevation of the arm(12) _ _ Arm compression sleeves(12) _ Compression pump(12) _ _ Lymphatic massage(12) _ _ Therapeutic modalities _ Strength training program(12,13) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveProgression will vary based on the approach selected and the response to treatmentTo be determined by the treating OT; may include donning of arm compression sleeves at home _ _ Educate patient on proper care of the upper extremity .

desired outcomes and related outcome mea: improved physical health, including increased cardiopulmonary function, improved immune system response, etc.–As evidenced by physical examinations (performed every 3 to 6 months for the first 3 years and every 6 to 12 months foryears 4 and 5, and annually thereafter)
increased functional mobility for ADLs/IADLs–ADL indexes (FIM, Barthel Index)–DASH Outcome Measure
decrease in fatigue–Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (MFI)–Piper Fatigue Scale (self-report)
improved quality of life–Quality of Life Index–SF-36

maintenance or prevention: For patients with a significant risk of developing breast cancer (as calculated by an oncologist based on family history, presence of BRCA1 gene or BRCA2  gene mutations, and other pertinent factors), prophylactic double mastectomy with immediate reconstructive surgery often is recommended as a means of prevention(1)
Annual mammograms are utilized both as a method of early detection for breast cancer and as a means of follow-up/monitoring  in patients with a history of breast cancer(1,2)

The American Cancer Society and the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO)clinical guidelines for follow-up  care for patients recovering from breast cancer are as follows:(16) Regular history, physical examination, and mammography as part of follow-up  care Physical examinations should be performed every 3 to 6 months for the first 3 years and every 6 to 12 months for years 4 and 5, and annually thereafter For women who have undergone breast-conserving  surgery, a posttreatment mammogram should be obtained yearly on the treated breast and also on the intact contralateral breast Complete blood counts, chemistry panels, bone scans, PET scans, MRI, and/or tumor markers are not recommended for routine follow-up  care in an otherwise asymptomatic patient with no specific findings on clinical examination

The ASCO clinical practice guidelines for pharmacologic interventions for breast cancer risk reduction are as follows:(17) Physicians should discuss the use of tamoxifen (20mg/day for 5 years) as an option to reduce the risk of estrogen receptor positive breast cancer in women at increased risk ≥ 35 years of age Physicians should discuss the use of raloxifene (60mg/day for 5 years) and exemestane (25mg/day for 5 years) as an option to reduce the risk of breast cancer in postmenopausal women Women who are at an increased risk for breast cancer are defined as individuals with a 5-year  projected absolute risk of breast cancer ≥ 1.66% based on the National Cancer Institute Breast Cancer Risk Assessment Tool or equivalent measure or women with lobular carcinoma in situ The use of selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) or aromatase inhibitors to lower breast cancer risk is not recommended outside of a clinical trial Healthcare providers are encouraged to discuss the option of chemoprevention with women who are at increased risk for breast cancer. Risks and benefits of each chemoprevention treatment should be discussed Annual mammograms, breast MRI, and laboratory tests as indicated; patient instruction in monthly breast self-examination(1,2) Smoking cessation; reduction of alcohol intake(1)
Risk for developing lymphedema can be minimized by implementing precautions with the involved upper extremity
patient education: Provide patient and family member(s) with information about the diagnosis and complications of breast cancer, as well as the goals of occupational therapy throughout the course of therapy
See the Resource Library on the National Breast Cancer Foundation website, http://www.nationalbreastcancer.org/about-breast-cancer
Information for patients, family members, and professionals about breast cancer can be found on the National Cancer Institute website, https://www.cancer.gov/types/breast

Breast Cancer Now is a nonprofit organization in the United Kingdom; the website provides information and resources for patients and families affected by breast cancer: https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/

The National Breast Cancer Foundation is a community-funded  organization in Australia raising money for research into the prevention and cure of breast cancer: https://nbcf.org.au/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
